title: Do you use emojis in serious conversations? - Quora

response.answer_text: In a formal writing (professional, academic, technical, legal), never. In a personal, casual exchange about a serious subject, yes. Serious discussions about personal issues should not be happening in writing. But they do, unfortunately. I sometimes include statements for context that are not at issue, but from time to time the other correspondent (usually the one who brought up some serious subject in the first place!) will read any such setting statement I include as some counter-assault, forgetting that I don't even want to have that discussion, I will provide as much clarity as I can. I have never figured out how—HOW!—recalling the setting could be viewed as a counter-assault, but some people have the gift. As such, I have found efficiency in a well-placed emoji. Take the sentence, “Remember, when we were at the Just Pikt Market [______], my friends walked in and you made that condescending comment” OPTION 1: “…Market, which was really fun and I'm glad we went, my friends…”. OPTION 2: “…Market 🤗, my friends…”. Quick, to the point, less wordy. >BOOM<…🤔…😃→💥 😉

No, because I’ve never conducted a serious conversation via text. When it matters, I speak by voice, preferably in person. I’ve had some fairly serious email interchanges over the years, so it’s possible that I may have thrown in a :) to indicate a change of tone, but that’s about it. In official, formal or professional correspondence, no, never ever.

I’m a big fan of words. I rarely use emojis at all. But if I do it could be in any sort of conversation. I’m more likely to text a meme that has words than a smiley face or whatever. Or just say what I want to say in my own words.
